docs.lead_paragraph: The ancient art of surgery is on the move again. For hundreds of years most surgical procedures were done at home on the kitchen table. Only in the last century did advances in medical technology move them into hospital operating rooms. Now much of surgery is traveling again, into the less expensive settings of doctors' private offices, and this has set off an escalating nationwide debate on how to insure patients' safety as the complicated modern technology of anesthesia and surgery floats free of hospital regulations back into less restricted settings.

headline.main: Surgeons Leaving The O.R. For the Office

docs.abstract: Much surgery now is moving from operating rooms to less expensive settings of doctors' private offices; trend sets off escalating nationwide debate on how to insure patients' safety as complicated modern technology of anesthesia and surgery floats free of hospital settings back into less restricted settings; only a few states have enacted legislation dealing with office surgery, but virtually all are examining issue because of a few widely publicized deaths and injuries; photos of Dr Marc E Koch lugging around cases of portable anesthesia equipment from surgery to surgery (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a move that could signal tough competition for on-line pharmacies, the CVS Corporation said yesterday that it had purchased Soma.com, the first Internet drugstore, for $30 million in CVS stock. The deal, expected to close next month, gives CVS a head start over other established drugstore chains like the Walgreen Company and Rite Aid that have yet to bring their offerings fully on line, analysts said. Still, they added, the low price is an indication of the slow progress on-line pharmacies have made.

headline.main: CVS Makes an Internet Move, Purchasing an On-Line Drugstore

docs.abstract: CVS Corp, in move that could signal tough competition for on-line pharmacies, purchases Soma.com, first Internet drugstore, for $30 million in CVS stock; deal gives CVS head start over other established chains like Walgreen Co and Rite Aid that have yet to bring their offerings fully on line; also means that nearly all insured customers who visit Soma site will have their prescriptions covered; CVS says it has more than 55 million prescription customers and more than 9,000 insurance providers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Michael M. Weinstein (Economic Scene, May 13) observes that Congress might consider merging health care benefits with the minimum wage. Such a change should have been made long ago. Compensation is traditionally composed of three components: cash, retirement (Social Security) and health insurance. But the minimum wage was designed with only two components. A raise in the minimum wage would be an opportunity to rectify this. In fact, 25 cents, 50 cents or even $1 of any potential increase could easily be devoted to health care insurance.
docs.abstract: Letter from Kenneth S Abramowitz says May 13 Economic Scene column noted that Congress might consider merging health care benefits with minimum wage, a change that should have been made long ago

docs.lead_paragraph: Seats in the State Senate become vacant with all the frequency of snow in May, and incumbents usually depart for better jobs, retirement or the hereafter, not because they have lost an election. A real contest is rare. One with implications for control of the Senate is rarer still. That state of affairs explains why New York's top political figures have lavished so much attention on the May 25 special election in Rockland and Orange Counties to replace Senator Joseph R. Holland, a Republican. In one of the state's few true swing districts, each party is heaping resources on the race.

headline.main: Local Race, Statewide Ripples; Parties Place High Value On Seat In New York Senate

docs.abstract: Article discusses importance being placed on special May 25 New York State senate election in Rockland and Orange Counties to replace Republican Sen Joseph R Holland; both Democratic candidate Kenneth Zebrowski and his Republican opponent, Thomas P Morahan, discusses importance of election in one of state's few true swing districts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Before Chris Osgood and the Red Wings flew to Denver for today's playoff game, the injured goalie practiced with his troubled team in Detroit, genuflecting repeatedly on his tender right knee like a reverent man in church. Up and down went Osgood, bouncing the padded knee off the ice, flexing it as he kicked at pucks. Directly behind his net, on the boards below the rink glass in Joe Louis Arena, a blue-and-white advertisement for a health-care company showed big crosses and shields. Should Osgood return to uniform, Detroit feels it might again have net protection after yielding 11 goals in its last two games. Without him, they are merely the Wings and a prayer.
docs.abstract: Detroit Red Wings hope injured goalie Chris Osgood will be able to help in playoff game against Denver (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Liana Lynn Huth was married yesterday to Nathaniel Gray Farnham at Studio 450 in New York. The Rev. Dr. George Koury performed the nondenominational ceremony. The couple, both 32, work in the music industry in New York. The bride is a director of tour marketing at Columbia Records, and the bridegroom is a talent agent at Little Big Man Booking, an agency that arranges tours for bands.

docs.lead_paragraph: An Administration plan to require cleaner gasoline and automobiles that emit less pollution, described by officials as the most ambitious anti-pollution initiative of the Clinton Presidency, is drawing heavy lobbying by environmentalists and industry and strong interest by politicians eyeing next year's Presidential campaign. The Environmental Protection Agency estimates that imposing the higher standards would reduce respiratory illnesses and save the lives of up to 2,800 Americans a year. These improvements would come at substantial cost -- $3.5 billion annually, five times as much as any other Clinton Administration rule aimed at specific sources of pollution, according to the agency.

headline.main: Auto Pollution Plan Is Drawn Into a Vortex

docs.abstract: Clinton Adminstration proposal to require cleaner gasoline and automobiles that emit fewer pollutants is drawing heavy lobbying by environmentalists and industry; table showing anticipated reductions in nitrogen oxides; EPA estimates higher standards would reduce respiratory illness and save lives of up to 2,800 Americans a year, at cost of $3.5 billion annually; Republicans are keeping close eye on Vice Pres Gore's strong support for measures, particularly those affecting sport utility vehicles, in hopes of using issue in Presidential campaign (M

docs.lead_paragraph: PAUL MISTRETTA and Priscilla Cipollini were veterans of the Long Beach single life when they happened to buy mirror-image condominiums along the boardwalk with facing terraces. One thing led to another, and last June they got married. Now the couple -- he's 35, she's 37 -- has just moved into a spacious new $375,000 home in Long Beach built in a style that the developer describes as Victorian Colonial. It has four bedrooms, a fireplace and a view of Reynolds Channel, which is named for William H. Reynolds, who developed Long Beach as a planned community, starting in 1906.

headline.main: Long Beach, Young Again; Once an Elegant Resort, Then a Family Haven, Now on a Quiet Comeback

docs.abstract: Article describes quiet but impressive comeback of once fashionable Long Island resort town of Long Beach, which was developed by William H Reynolds starting in 1906; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DAVID PARSONS sounded distressed. ''Lately, every time I start a new project, I get unnerved,'' he said over lunch in Manhattan recently. Although this 39-year-old dancer-choreographer looks like a hunky, happy-go-lucky movie star, during this conversation he came across as an angst-ridden artist. ''In the back of my mind, there's always the word 'accessible' that's constantly thrown at me as an insult. What does it mean? That I attract the masses? That's bad? My work's not about getting people to love me. It's about following what I want to do.'' Ever since he established his modern-dance company 12 years ago, some critics have called his work superficial, accusing him of catering to the lowest common denominator. But why do their opinions affect him so deeply now? After all, he has had plenty of time to build defenses. Moreover, his company consistently attracts new fans, makes money and pleases many more critics than it disappoints. Obviously something else was wrong.

headline.main: Dancing On Top of the World, With Malaise

docs.abstract: Valerie Gladstone article on Parsons Dance Company, which is in rehearsal for two week stint at Joyce Theater; program will feature new David Parsons work Fill the Wood With Light and six works by Robert Battle, including four New York premieres and world premier of Rush Hour; photo (M)
